plan: In the initial rounds, I'll test aggressive bidding by occasionally bidding above my value to explore opponents' thresholds. I'll also try conservative bids below my value to gauge their aggressiveness. Mid-game, I'll analyze patterns in opponents' bids to adjust my strategy, possibly incorporating mixed strategies based on observed behaviors. Towards the end, I'll aim to maximize profit by aligning bids closer to my value, adjusting for any predictable patterns. Throughout, I'll track outcomes to refine my approach, ensuring a balance between risk-taking and profit maximization.

I will start by testing the dominant strategy of bidding my exact value to establish a baseline. I'll then explore slightly aggressive strategies, bidding 1-3 dollars above my value to gauge competitors' responses. If opponents consistently bid their values, I'll try underbidding by 1-3 dollars to maximize profit margins when winning. I'll also introduce randomness by occasionally bidding significantly lower or higher to gather data on opponents' reactions. By monitoring patterns, I'll adjust strategies to exploit any predictable behavior from Andy and Charles, aiming to maximize long-term profit through adaptive bidding.

In the first five rounds, I'll bid my exact value to gather baseline data. For the next five rounds, I'll experiment with aggressive bids, adding $5 to my value to test if overbidding increases my win rate. In the final five rounds, I'll try underbidding by $5 to assess if conservative bids can still secure wins with less risk. Throughout, I'll analyze opponents' patterns to adjust strategies dynamically. The goal is to identify if deviations from the dominant strategy can consistently improve profits or if sticking to value-based bids is optimal.
